chapter.para: A complete SciDB installation is a multi-database environment that includes the core SciDB engine, Postgres, the open source SQL database engine which is used for system catalog data, as well as ScaLAPACK/MPI which is used as a computational engine for dense linear algebra.

note.para: SciDB installation must be done by an account with root privileges.

section.title: Installation Resources
section.para:
The linchpin of the SciDB installation procedure is the Cluster Install script, located at www.scidb.org/forum/viewforum.php?f=16. In addition, these other resources are available:
Configurator (generates a config.ini file from your interactive input): https://github.com/Paradigm4/configurator.
A how-to video on installing SciDB is available here: http://www.paradigm4.com/scidb-installation-video/.
A backup-and-restore script, useful if you are upgrading from a previous version of SciDB. The script is available on your SciDB cluster (provided your existing installation is version 14.3 or later; previous versions did not include this script) in /opt/scidb/14.3/bin/scidb_backup.py or /opt/scidb/14.8/bin/scidb_backup.py.
An appendix describing the detailed steps which are automatically performed by the Cluster Install script. If local policies prevent you from running the cluster install script, you can use this appendix as a guide to manual installation. See .
See the remainder of the chapter for more details about the installation process and files.

note.para: Previous versions (14.3 and 14.8) included a script to help you install without root privilegesâ€”on CentOS/RHEL only. However, we are not aware of anyone actively using that script, so in this release it is not supported. If you need such a script, contact us at support@paradigm4.com.

section.title: First-Time Installation
section.para: If you are installing SciDB for the first time on a cluster, the process is straightforward:

step.para: Prepare the platform. This includes creating or adjusting user accounts and configuring storage for the SciDB database files. For details, see .
Prepare a configuration file for SciDB. See .
Run the cluster install script. See .

section.title: Preparing the Platform
section.para: Before installing SciDB, the following steps are required to prepare a cluster for running SciDB. Many of these steps must be executed as the Linux 'root' account.

section.title: Prepare Accounts
section.para: Before you install SciDB, you need to ensure that you have a user account under which SciDB processes -- on all servers of the cluster -- will run. This will also be the owner of all data and log files created by SciDB, and it is the account that initializes, starts, and stops the SciDB cluster. This account must have passwordless SSH access configured between the default coordinator server and all other servers in the cluster. Throughout this documentation, this account is referred to as the scidb account, although strictly speaking, it can be any account with the appropriate settings.

In addition to setting up the scidb account, you may need to perform these tasks depending on your operating system:
Ubuntu does not enable root login by default. To enable root login on Ubuntu, run the following command:sudo passwdSudo will prompt you for your password, and then ask you to supply a new password for root.
For CentOS and RHEL, you should create a user account (adduser), and provide sudo access for this account. For details, see your OS documentation. If you need to install sudo, execute the following command (as root):yum install sudo

section.title: Configure Storage

note.para: This action must be performed by a user with sudo privileges on each server in the cluster. Once created, the base path should be owned by the account used by SciDB.

section.title: Configuring SciDB
section.para: This section shows a configuration file: the result of using the configurator (https://github.com/Paradigm4/configurator) utility. The configurator will place the file wherever you choose. Then, the Cluster Install script will move the file to its proper location on the default coordinator server -- in /opt/scidb/&scidb_version;/etc/config.ini.

The configuration 'test1' below is an example of the configuration for a single-node, four-instance system:[test1] server-0=localhost,3 db_user=test1user db_passwd=test1passwd install_root=/opt/scidb/&scidb_version; metadata=/opt/scidb/&scidb_version;/share/scidb/meta.sql pluginsdir=/opt/scidb/&scidb_version;/lib/scidb/plugins logconf=/opt/scidb/&scidb_version;/share/scidb/log4cxx.properties base-path=/home/scidb/data base-port=1239 network-buffer=1024 mem-array-threshold=1024 smgr-cache-size=1024 execution-threads=16 result-prefetch-queue-size=4 result-prefetch-threads=4

section.title: Upgrading SciDB
section.para:
SciDB
upgrading
upgrade SciDB
versions
SciDB This section describes the process for installing SciDB 14.12 on a cluster where a previous version of SciDB is already installed. This section uses the following conventions:
To represent your current version: scidbOldVersion.
To represent the new version that you are installing: scidbNewVersion.

For example, if you are upgrading from 14.8 to 14.12:
scidbOldVersion = 14.8
scidbNewVersion = 14.12
If you are installing SciDB 14.12 on a cluster with a previous version of SciDB, perform the following steps:

step.para: Backup. If your existing installation is 14.3 or later, you should back up your data using the script, scidb_backup.py. This file is in the /opt/scidb/<scidbOldVersion>/bin folder. (If your existing installation is a version earlier than 14.3, you must perform manual backup.) First, confirm that you have enough storage space, because the following command will backup all your SciDB arrays. From the scidb user account, run the backup script. As an example, the following command creates a folder, ./mySavedArrays, and saves all of your arrays, using the OPAQUE format, into that folder:$ /opt/scidb/14.8/bin/scidb_backup.py -s opaque mySavedArraysFor usage details of the backup script, see the SciDB Reference Manual.

note.para: If your existing installation is earlier than 14.8, do not use the OPAQUE format for this step. OPAQUE is guaranteed to work only between consecutive releases of SciDB.

step.para: If you want to use the SciDB configuration from your existing installation as the basis for the 14.12 configuration file, make a backup copy of it somewhere. By default, the file is in the following location:opt/scidb/scidbOldVersion/etc/config.ini

OPTIONAL. You can run multiple versions of SciDB. However, if you need only the latest version of SciDB, you can remove the previous version. If you installed to the default location, run the following command to remove the old version:sudo rm -Rf /opt/scidb/scidbOldVersion/

Remove any older version of SciDB. For CentOS and RHEL, remove scidb.list.* and p4.list.* from /etc/yum.repos.d, then perform the following command. yum list | grep scidb |awk '{print $1}' | grep '[a-zA-Z]' | xargs sudo rpm -e For Ubuntu, remove scidb.list.* and p4.list.* from /etc/apt/sources.list.d, then perform the following command.dpkg --list | grep scidb |awk '{print $2}' | xargs sudo dpkg --purge

Upgrade. Perform the following steps to upgrade to version 14.12 of SciDB.
Set up your configuration file. If you are starting from the configuration file you saved in step 3, be sure to change all occurrences of scidbOldVersion to scidbNewVersion. After you edit the file, make a note of where you save it.
Typically, the following settings are affected:install_root=/opt/scidb/14.8 pluginsdir=/opt/scidb/14.8/lib/scidb/plugins logconf=/opt/scidb/14.8/share/scidb/log4cxx.properties
Also, be sure to add the following setting to the configuration file (if it does not already exist):enable-catalog-upgrade=trueFor more details about the configuration file, see .
Run the cluster install procedure, available at www.scidb.org/forum/viewforum.php?f=16. On the command line that invokes cluster install, include the configuration file (the one you saved in step 5a) as a parameter. See the cluster install README file for details.
Restart SciDB. Use the following command:
scidb.py initall scidb_cluster_name
If you get an error that says SciDB needs to upgrade the system catalog, and that the action failed, make sure to set the enable-catalog-upgrade parameter to true, as detailed in step 6a.

Restore. After you have the new version of SciDB running, restore any data that you backed up in step 1. For example, if you used the command in step 1 to backup your arrays, you would run the following command to restore them:$ /opt/scidb/14.12/bin/scidb_backup.py -r opaque mySavedArrays
